DataElement.preferredName: Primary Immunodeficiency Syndrome Required Ongoing Treatment Immune Globulin Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The indicator of whether or not the primary immunodeficiency syndrome required ongoing treatment of immune globulin.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Primary Immunodeficiency Syndrome Requirement Treatment Ongoing Therapeutic Immune Globulin
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Immunodeficiency disease that arises independent of another pathologic process, disease, or injury.:Something that is a necessary condition; something that is obligatory._An indication that a subject is still undergoing therapy to prevent, mitigate or cure a disease._A preparation of plasma proteins derived from the pooled plasma of adult donors. Largely comprised of IgG antibodies, therapeutic immune globulin provides passive immunization by increasing the recipient's serum levels of circulating antibodies. IgG antibodies have multiple functions, including binding to and neutralizing bacterial toxins; opsonization of pathogens; activation of complement; and suppression of pathogenic cytokines and phagocytes through binding to CD5, interleukin-1a (IL-1a), interleukin 6 (IL-6), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), and T-cell receptors. Therapeutic immune globulin may diminish pathogenic mechanisms in some autoimmune diseases by binding to and inhibiting the activity of autoantibodies. (NCI04)

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Immunodeficiency disease that arises independent of another pathologic process, disease, or injury.

Concepts.definition: Immunodeficiency disease that arises independent of another pathologic process, disease, or injury.

Property.preferredName: Requirement Treatment Ongoing Therapeutic Immune Globulin
Property.preferredDefinition: Something that is a necessary condition; something that is obligatory._An indication that a subject is still undergoing therapy to prevent, mitigate or cure a disease._A preparation of plasma proteins derived from the pooled plasma of adult donors. Largely comprised of IgG antibodies, therapeutic immune globulin provides passive immunization by increasing the recipient's serum levels of circulating antibodies. IgG antibodies have multiple functions, including binding to and neutralizing bacterial toxins; opsonization of pathogens; activation of complement; and suppression of pathogenic cytokines and phagocytes through binding to CD5, interleukin-1a (IL-1a), interleukin 6 (IL-6), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), and T-cell receptors. Therapeutic immune globulin may diminish pathogenic mechanisms in some autoimmune diseases by binding to and inhibiting the activity of autoantibodies. (NCI04)

Concepts.definition: Something that is a necessary condition; something that is obligatory.
An indication that a subject is still undergoing therapy to prevent, mitigate or cure a disease.

A preparation of plasma proteins derived from the pooled plasma of adult donors. Largely comprised of IgG antibodies, therapeutic immune globulin provides passive immunization by increasing the recipient's serum levels of circulating antibodies. IgG antibodies have multiple functions, including binding to and neutralizing bacterial toxins; opsonization of pathogens; activation of complement; and suppression of pathogenic cytokines and phagocytes through binding to CD5, interleukin-1a (IL-1a), interleukin 6 (IL-6), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), and T-cell receptors. Therapeutic immune globulin may diminish pathogenic mechanisms in some autoimmune diseases by binding to and inhibiting the activity of autoantibodies. (NCI04)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).
